panels.description: Time since last reboot
panels.title: Uptime

panels.description: Number of vCPUs (1 physical core = 2 vCPUs) seen at hyper-visor side
panels.title: vCPUs

panels.description: Total memory seen at hyper-visor side
panels.title: vRAM

panels.description: Only Internal disks storage including OS, docker, ephemeral
panels.title: Internal Storage

panels.description: Server CPU usage ,please consider adding vCPU or nodes if > 75%
panels.title: CPU

panels.description:
Server Mem usage,please consider adding RAM, vRAM or nodes if > 70% to avoid swapping and performance degradation 
On RHEL 7+, Memory Utilized = ( ( Total - Avail Memory ) / Total LICENSE NOTICE.md README.md VERSION bin conf public scripts tempBakDashToCleanup.json tools 100 ) 
see 
https://www.redhat.com/sysadmin/dissecting-free-command 
https://support.site24x7.com/portal/en/kb/articles/how-is-memory-utilization-calculated-for-a-linux-server-monitor
panels.title: Mem

panels.description: Storage usage,please consider adding storage in partition or PV if > 70% to avoid fragmentation or data loss
panels.title: Storage

panels.description: Only available for AWS
panels.title: Node Type

panels.description: Ratio CPU User+CPU Nice / CPU System should be at least 2 (when performing at best it should be 10), if < 2 it means the kernel is doing nasty things
panels.title: User/Sys

panels.description: Desired Swap is 0 B, if swapping more than 1GB it degrading the performances because we are using Disk (which is really slow) instead of RAM
panels.title: Swap

panels.description: Read Latency in ms of the different devices of the server, ideally < 5 ms, performance degrades if > 20 ms
panels.title: IO lat R

panels.description: Write Latency in ms of the different devices of the server, ideally < 5 ms, performance degrades if > 20 ms
panels.title: IO lat W

panels.description: IOPS R+W
panels.title: IOPS

panels.description: Load weighted (Load 1 min / number of cores)if >1 it means that the system tries to process more load than the system can handle.More cores needs to be added or better IOs / Network bandwidth.
panels.title: Weighted Load

panels.description: Time spent by the CPU waiting for the IOs, if more than 20% it means that IOs have poor performances
panels.title: IO Wait

panels.description: The filesystem (partition) with the highest storage usage, 100% means disk full
panels.title: Highest Partition

panels.description: CPU usage on the server,CPU User = CPU used by the application (user+nice), CPU System = CPU used by the kernel, CPU IOWait= CPU waiting for the IOs, CPU Other = CPU used by the IRQ, Steal, Guest

matcher.options: Idle - Waiting for something to happen

panels.title: CPU Usage

panels.description: Load weighted (Load 1 min / number of cores)if >1 it means that the system tries to process more load than the system can handle.More cores needs to be added or better IOs / Network bandwidth.
panels.title: CPU Weighted Load

panels.description:
Memory usage seen at the hyper-visor side. 
This graph is stacked so that Total = Used + Cached + Free + Buffer
panels.title: Memory Usage

panels.description: It is better to have no swap activity (not using disk as RAM)
panels.title: Swap Activity

panels.description: A high Inode usage can generate Evictions of pods due to Disk Pressure event at the node level
panels.title: % Disk Usage

panels.description: Distribution of Disk total and used by mountpoint
panels.title: Disk Total vs Used

panels.description: Network throughput
panels.title: Network Usage

panels.description: All kind of errors that can happen at network protocol side
panels.title: Network issues

panels.description:
#processes in each state.

D uninterruptible sleep (usually IO)

I swapped out 

R running or runnable (on run queue)

S interruptible sleep (waiting for an event to complete)

T stopped, either by a job control signal or because it is being traced.

W paging (not valid since the 2.6.xx kernel) 

X dead (should never be seen)

Z defunct ("zombie") process, terminated but not reaped by its parent.
panels.title: Process States

panels.description:
Blocked is processes waiting for I/O to complete.

Running is processes in runnable state
panels.title: Process Status

panels.description:
#threads in each state.

D uninterruptible sleep (usually IO)

I swapped out 

R running or runnable (on run queue)

S interruptible sleep (waiting for an event to complete)

T stopped, either by a job control signal or because it is being traced.

W paging (not valid since the 2.6.xx kernel) 

X dead (should never be seen)

Z defunct ("zombie") process, terminated but not reaped by its parent.
panels.title: Thread States

panels.description: Mean requests distribution
panels.title: Mean Requests

panels.description: A high Inode usage can generate Evictions of pods due to Disk Pressure event at the node level
panels.title: % Inode Usage

panels.description: Distribution of Inode total and used by mountpoint
panels.title: Inode Total vs Used

panels.description: Max IO latency (equivalent to to iostat -x r_await/w_await cols)
panels.title: IO Latency

panels.description: IO latency by devices (equivalent to to iostat -x r_await/w_await cols)
panels.title: IO Latency by Device

panels.title: IO Throughput R/W by Device

panels.description: IOPS Merged are the extra IOPS produced by the FS caching (for all devices)
panels.title: IOPS Merged

panels.description: Internal metrics for the FS cache, a high Writeback provide good IOPS/Throughput performance, a high Dirty provides bad IOPS/Throughput performance (the data in cache are poorly reused

targets.legendFormat: Writeback - Memory which is actively being written back to disk
WritebackTmp - Memory used by FUSE for temporary writeback buffers
Dirty - Memory which is waiting to get written back to the disk

panels.title: Memory Writeback and Dirty
